content: Andrei Granovitch is a professor, Chief of the Department of Invertebrate Zoology at the St-Petersburg State University. His research interests include microevolution, population biology,parasitology, malacology, zoology. He leads the Littorina microevolution group, which studies speciation in closely related species of genus Littorina.

content: Since my first year at Biological faculty of the SPbSU I specialized in molecular aspects of marine invertebrate physiology, including immune and adaptive mechanisms. Part of my interests focuses on different types of stressors and their action on marine invertebrates in arctic and subarctic regions. Among them there are natural (low salinity, desiccation, hypoxia, etc.) and human-related (different types of pollution) ones. Littorinas are among my favorite organisms to deal with. Many facets of their biology fascinate to be studied: plasticity and adaptation to a microhabitat, interactions with parasites and mutualists, sympatry with the closest relatives, etc.

content:
I am a Senior lecturer at Department of invertebrate zoology ( Faculty of Biology, St Petersburg State University ).
My interests range widely in marine ecology: structure and dynamics of marine communities; role of interspecific interactions in communities; assessment of anthropogenic impact on coastal and marine habitats; microevolutionary processes in sympatric populations of closely related species; methods of statistical analysis.

I am a Senior lecturer at Department of invertebrate zoology ( Faculty of Biology, St Petersburg State University ).
My interests range widely in marine ecology: structure and dynamics of marine communities; role of interspecific interactions in communities; assessment of anthropogenic impact on coastal and marine habitats; microevolutionary processes in sympatric populations of closely related species; methods of statistical analysis.

title: Ksenia Volovik

content: My general research area is molecular mechanisms and evolution of adaptations in natural populations. I am interested in all molecular changes at DNA and RNA level (structural and regulatory mutations, gene expression profiles, chromosomal rearrangements and genome divergence), and how they affect organisms in their natural environments. I am also interested in evolutionary histories of genes and how they can be used to reconstruct histories of populations and species. My primary research objects are intertidal snails of genus Littorina that show amazing variation in all possible traits within and between the species and are adapted to very different environments.
summary: My general research area is molecular mechanisms and evolution of adaptations in natural populations. title: Marina Panova

content:
In 2018–2019, I finished a one-year program “Bioinformatics for Biologists” at the Bioinformatics Institute. During the study project “Development of the library for express analysis of FASTA/FASTQ files” I developed functions for filtering reads of low-quality / duplicates / a particular motif using biopython library. The second project “Effect of smoking on epigenome of human leukocytes” was devoted to search of differentially methylated CpG-islands.
Since 2019 I'm involved in a project “Ecological and molecular basis of microevolution: a model of parallel speciation in complexes of cryptic species of littoral mollusks”, where I analyze proteomes and metabolomes of littorines from two groups of cryptic species: “saxatilis” and “obtusata”.

summary: The recent intensification of energy resource exploration and human activities in the Barents Sea (BS) requires a more thorough assessment of the natural and anthropogenic impact of hydrocarbons on the environment. We analyzed a wide set of sensitive indicators, including hydrocarbon molecular markers and organic matter (OM) maturity parameters in the Holocene sediments from three regions of the BS: the Kola-Kanin Monocline (KKM), the Svalbard shelf, and the Shtokman gas-condensate field (GCF). An increase in pyrogenic polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons toward the core surface traces the intensification of anthropogenic contamination in the KKM region during last century. An input of highly mature OM from the eroded coal rocks of Barentsburg were confirmed by comparison of biomarker distribution in sediments and coals. An increase in biogenic hopanes and hopenes content down-core, and a crude-oil stage of OM maturity in surface sediments of the Shtokman GCF attests to hydrocarbons migration from subsurface strata.
title: Hydrocarbon molecular markers in the Holocene bottom sediments of the Barents Sea as indicators of natural and anthropogenic impacts

summary: Fertilization (gamete fusion followed by zygote formation) is a multistage process. Each stage is mediated by ligand-receptor recognition of gamete interaction molecules. This recognition includes the movement of sperm in the gradient of egg chemoattractants, destruction of the egg envelope by acrosomal proteins, etc. Gametic incompatibility is one of the mechanisms of reproductive isolation. It is based on species-specific molecular interactions that prevent heterospecific fertilization. Although gametic incompatibility may occur in any sexually reproducing organism, it has been studied only in a few model species. Gamete interactions in different taxa involve generally similar processes, but they often employ non-homologous molecules. Gamete recognition proteins evolve rapidly, like immunity proteins, and include many taxon-specific families.
title: The Molecular Mechanisms of Gametic Incompatibility in Invertebrates

title: Norway 2019

content:
Ecological and molecular backgroung of speciation: the model of parallel speciation in the complex of cryptic species of intertidal molluscs RSF #19-14-00321
The project is devoted to the analysis of processes of intraspecific divergence, the formation of distinct intraspecific groups in the scope of the feasibility of the parallel, unidirectional morphological and functional changes of the groups of individuals in different parts of the species range, in locations with similar gradients of environmental factors (parallel “race formation”). The proof of this phenomenon raises an even more important question about the possibility of a parallel, independent formation of similar groups of species rank, repeated at different parts of the species range. This model of speciation is an alternative to the model, which recognizes unique, single and highly stochastic speciation followed by dispersal (young species range formation) and the formation of zones of secondary contact with the populations of the ancestral species.
In the framework of the formulated fundamental problem, we offer, on the one hand, to demonstrate the repetitive acts of differentiation of populations of species in ecological gradients at the level of the phenotype and genotype in different geographical regions, and on the other hand, to verify the possibility of independent divergence of the young cryptic species in the same geographic locations on basis of the same genetic data.
The selected model system - two groups of cryptic species of the genus Littorina subgenus Neritrema (Mollusca: Caenogastropoda: Littorinidae) - “saxatilis” (L.arcana, L.compressa, L.saxatilis) and “obtusata” (L.fabalis, L.obtusata), which form sympatric populations, and whose environmental preferences overlap to varying degree.
The project's objective is to carry out comprehensive comparisons within the two categories of objects: (1) intraspecific ecological groups within each of the three species from “saxatilis” group (a natural model of the situation “before the speciation”); (2) young species (respectively, interspecies analysis of all five of these species, the natural model of the situation “after the speciation”).
We plan to perform a comprehensive comparative analysis of eight populations of each species from 4 geographically distant regions (2 populations from each region - the British Isles, the Atlantic Coast (1); Breton peninsula, the Channel (2); The northern part of the Scandinavian Peninsula, the Norwegian Sea (3); Kola peninsula, the Barents sea (4)). For each of the analyzed categories we will obtain a complex description phenotype of individuals at the morphological (morphometric analysis of shell) and molecular levels (profiles of proteins expressed and metabolites produced), description of environmental preferences (distribution in the intertidal zone, the food spectrum), and genotyping based on restriction-site associated DNA markers (RADseq-tags).
In total, such a multilevel analysis will show the formation of parallel rows of variability in different populations of different species at the level of phenotype; genetic analysis will reveal adaptively significant loci and assess whether their composition is similar across species. In addition, it will provide an opportunity to understand how likely is the independent divergence of young species within the cryptic groups at each location.
The project will be carried out using the equipment of the St. Petersburg State University resource centers “Centre for Molecular and Cell Technologies” and “Environmental Safety Observatory”. Completion of the project will allow to determine the molecular mechanisms of formation of a complex of closely related species and ecological intraspecific morphs. The new data will be important for understanding of the overall process of speciation.
summary: Ecological and molecular backgroung of speciation: the model of parallel speciation in the complex of cryptic species of intertidal molluscs
title: Parallel speciation in littorines

content:
Local evolutionary adaptations and host-parasite interactions: multilevel analysis of closely related gastropod species RFBR #19-04-00392
Biological adaptation is a key process concerning such important scientific areas as organism homeostasis, interactions with environment, speciation, etc. This determines the importance of studies of adaptations and its mechanisms. This project is devoted to analysis of how organisms living in heterogenic environment make their adaption to biotopes occupied. Intertidal snails of the genus Littorina were chosen as a model system. Metabolomics and proteomics as principal approaches will be used for characterizing physiological features of animals collected from wild populations. We will analyze effects of abiotic factors on organisms’ physiology in dependence on species, intertidal level, trematode infection and gut microsymbionts composition in example of snails; similar analysis of population partitioning will be performed for trematode parasites. So, within one project proteomics, metabolomics, molecular marker analysis, metagenomic analysis of gut microbiome, parasitology and population ecology will be jointed.
Our goal is to reveal molecular mechanisms of local adaptations on the basis of metabolomic and proteomic profiles analysis in the context of population ecology (intraspecies level) and evolution (interspecies level in the group of closely related species). The effect of trematode parasites on host adaptability and physiology will also be estimated. The relevance of the projects proposed is determined by contribution of expected results to several fundamental biological problems, such as, molecular mechanisms of adaptation; intraspecies plasticity of these mechanisms and its reasons; speciation mechanisms; host-parasite interactions. Such a multifaceted approach puts the proposed project onto current edge of ecological and evolutionary biology and makes the expected results of high demand.
summary: Local evolutionary adaptations and host-parasite interactions: multilevel analysis of closely related gastropod species
title: Host-parasite co-speciation

summary: Although individual stages of spermatogenesis in _Littorina saxatilis_ are well studied at the electron microscopic level, the gonad structure and the spatial localization of gametes at different stages of maturation remain unclear. Using differential-interference contrast (DIC) for observations of fresh tissue we show that the mature testis consists of numerous ovoid lobules forming larger lobes. The lobules of intact mature testes of _L. saxatilis_ are filled with randomly arranged multicellular cysts containing gametes at different stages of maturation. Gametes within a cyst are highly synchronized in respect of the differentiation degree. At the same time, no spatial gradient in the arrangement of cysts according to the maturation degree of gametes in them was observed in any of the studied lobules. The male gonads contain cysts with early spermatids, mid, late spermatids, and spermatozoa. Using silver-staining, DAPI, and chromomycin A3 (CMA3) staining, we identify 20 main types of nucleus organization in differentiating sperm. Premature and mature male gonads contain cysts with a mosaic arrangement as well as rare solitary cyst cells, goniablast cysts, or separate spermatogonia in between them. Our data indicate that the testis structure in _L. saxatilis_ cannot be attributed to the tubular type, as previously thought. It corresponds to the lobular cyst type but individual lobules contain cysts with gametes at the same stage of development. It is similar to the testis structure of several fishes, amphibians, and _Drosophila melanogaster_. This type of the gonad organization has never been described in gastropods before.
title: Spermatogenesis and lobular cyst type of testes organization in marine gastropod Littorina saxatilis (Olivi 1792)

title: Expeditions

summary: People in our lab and our collaborators
title: People

summary: The consequences of changes in the genotype of an organism are involved into a system of hierarchical multiple compensation, from the molecular to the biocenotic level. In a way, the signal of hereditary change passes through a series of “system filters” at epigenetic, ontogenetic, physiological, behavioural, populational and biocenotic level. Each filter is represented by multiple feedbacks maintaining the integrity of systems at each level and at all the hierarchical levels taken together. It is in these “system filters” the adaptive nature of characters is formed representing the every individual as a subject to the Law of Multilevel Self-Organization. The emerging understanding of this provides a strong reason to change the evolutionary paradigm from the mainly selectogenetic to the mainly orthogenetic one.
title: Is Natural Selection still have to be Regarded A Foundation Stone of Evolutionary Process?

summary: Reproductive isolation is the key attribute of biological species and establishment of the reproductive barriers is an essential event for speciation. Among the mechanisms of reproductive isolation, gamete incompatibility due to the variability of gamete interaction proteins may drive fast divergence even in sympatry. However, the number of available models to study this phenomenon is limited. In case of internally fertilized invertebrates, models to study gamete incompatibility and sperm competition mechanisms are restricted to a single taxon: insects. Here, we propose a group of closely related Littorina species as a new model for such studies. Particularly since periwinkles are already thoroughly studied in terms of morphology, physiology, ecology, phylogeny, and ecological speciation. Earlier, we have identified the first species‐specific Littorina sperm protein (LOSP) with no known conservative domains or homologies. LOSP is relatively abundant component of sperm extracts and might be involved in gamete incompatibility. Here, we characterize its definitive localization and mRNA expression pattern in the male reproductive system by immunocytochemistry and RNA in situ hybridization. We demonstrate that LOSP distribution is limited to the parasperm cells. Losp gene expression occurs only at the early stages of parasperm development. The protein is stored within granules of mature parasperm and, most likely, is released after ejaculation inside female reproductive system. Thus, LOSP is the only described molluscan paraspermal protein to date, and there is a possibility for LOSP to be involved in gamete incompatibility since heterospermy is a common phenomenon among Littorina.
title: LOSP: A putative marker of parasperm lineage in male reproductive system of the prosobranch mollusk Littorina obtusata

content:
Environmental monitoring of Arctic coastal ecosystems: Sensitivity to petroleum pollution (Arctic EcoSens) RFBR #18-54-20001
The state of Arctic biocenoses reflects global dynamic processes associated with climate change and, at the same time, reflects local anthropogenic impact. In the Arctic, the rapid expansion of human economic activity such as oil and gas production is one of significant factors, which impact on natural communities requires a thorough assessment. In addition to practical significance, this situation also provides an opportunity to model biota dynamics in changing environmental conditions. In this regard, the main fundamental component of the project is the assessment of the degree of stability of Arctic biocenoses, the analysis of the mechanisms that ensure it in the gradient of environmental conditions, and development of new approaches for monitoring of Arctic biocenoses.
   To fullfill the project's goals, it is important that the structure of the complex “pollution effect” can be quantified as the ratio of the components of polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) of biogenic, petrogenic and pyrogenic origin (a “fingerprint” passport of PAH pollution at each site studied), and measuring the concentration of heavy metals (working package (WP) 1). This makes it possible to assess the correlation of the “pollution effect” with the structural biocenotic parameters of the model intertidal communities of salt marches and rocky intertidal sites (WP). Moreover, the use of experimental methods such as proteomics and metabolics to assess modell communities allows us to draw conclusions about the effect of factors and the state of biota (WP 3). The main objective of the project is to assess the impact of factors associated with oil and gas production and associated anthropogenic activity in the polar region on model biocenoses using modern geochemical, synecological and autecological approaches, modernization of the methodology for monitoring biocenoses of the Barents Sea at oil production sites, and exchange of experience between Russian and Norwegian research institutes and universities.
The project uses the strong side of decades-long scientific cooperation between Russia and Norway, which involves environmental monitoring of the Barents Sea, development of environmental impact standards for both countries.
summary: Environmental monitoring of Arctic coastal ecosystems: Sensitivity to petroleum pollution (Arctic EcoSens)
title: EcoSens

summary: Salinity is a crucial abiotic environmental factor for marine animals, affecting their physiology and geographic ranges. Deviation of environmental salinity from the organismal optimum range results in an osmotic stress in osmoconformers, which keep their fluids isotonic to the environment. The ability to overcome such stress is critical for animals inhabiting areas with considerable salinity variation, such as intertidal areas. In this study, we compared the reaction to mild water freshening (from 24 to 14 ‰) in two related species of intertidal snails, Littorina saxatilis and L. obtusata, with respect to several aspects: survival, behavior and proteomic changes. Among these species, L. saxatilis is more tolerant to low salinity and survives in estuaries. We found out that the response of these species was much milder (with no mortality or isolation reaction observed) and involved weaker proteomic changes than during acute stress (freshening from 24 to 10 ‰), characterized earlier. The proteomic response of the second species, L. obtusata, was weaker (6 % vs 10 % of regulated proteins) than that of L. saxatilis and engaged a mostly different set of proteins. Among proteins potentially involved in adaptation to low salinity, we identified enzymes of energetic metabolism and antioxidant response, chaperones, proteins of extracellular matrix and cytoskeleton, ion channels and regulators of cell growth and proliferation.
title: Mild osmotic stress in intertidal gastropods Littorina saxatilis and Littorina obtusata (Mollusca: Caenogastropoda): a proteomic analysis

summary: Salinity is one of the most important abiotic environmental factors for marine animals. If salinity deviates from optimum, adaptive mechanisms switch on to maintain organism’s physiological activity. In this study the proteome of the marine snails Littorina saxatilis from natural habitats was analyzed using differential 2D gel-electrophoresis (DIGE) with subsequent LC-MS/MS-identification of proteins. Approximately 10% of proteins were differentially expressed. Among them there were proteins of folding, antioxidant response, intercellular matrix, and metabolic enzymes. Proteomic changes observed in experimental hypoosmotic stress partially reproduced in the proteomes of molluscs that live in conditions of natural freshening (estuaries).
title: Mechanisms of adaption to salinity stress in marine gastropods Littorina saxatilis: a proteomic analysis

summary: The idea of parasitic systems, formulated by V.N. Beklemishev 70 years ago, represents a conceptual tool for the analysis of populational and biocoenotic roles of parasites. The questions concerning longterm stable persistence of host–parasite systems in communities can be discussed meaningfully only within this concept. Importantly, the set of terms elaborated within the parasitic system concept is applicable not only to parasitology, but also contributes to the general knowledge of life cycles of organisms and differences in the environment. This concept provides an opportunity for comprehensive analysis of systems, based on any type of stable biocoenotic interactions in the community (predation, commensalism, competition, etc.). Trematode-based parasitic systems, involving populations of intertidal mollusks of the genus Littorina, allow demonstrating how the strong “negative” effect of parasites on hosts at the individual level (complete parasitic castration) can be compensated at the population level. Such compensation functions as a prerequisite for maintaining long-term stable interactions between populations of parasites and their hosts within parasitic system (the ecosystem, biocoenotic level).
title: From host–parasite systems to parasitic systems: Interactions of littoral mollusks of the genus Littorina with their trematode parasites

summary: During recent years, the role of proteomics in ecology, population biology and evolutionary studies has been growing. It has been used effectively to resolve taxonomic ambiguity in closely related species and for detection of environmental effects on populations. The family Littorinidae (Gastropoda; periwinkles) includes a set of widely distributed species, which are important members of intertidal communities of the coasts around the world. Taxonomic relationships among several species, e.g. within the subgenus Neritrema, are still poorly understood. We explored proteomes of 3 closely related littorinid species (the so called ‘saxatilis’-group: Littorina arcana, L. compressa and L. saxatilis) from different tidal levels of one geographic area.
title: Measuring physiological similarity of closely related littorinid species: a proteomic insight

summary: North Atlantic Littorina species (periwinkles) of the subgenus Neritrema are represented by two groups of morphologically and phylogenetically closely related species—two sister species of the ‘obtusata’ group: Littorina obtusata (Linnaeus, 1758) and L. fabalis (W. Turton, 1825) and three sister species of the ‘saxatilis’ group: L. saxatilis (Olivi, 1792), L. arcana Hannaford Ellis, 1978 and L. compressa Jeffreys, 1865 (Reid, 1996; Reid, Dyal & Williams, 2012). Populations of these species sympatrically inhabit the intertidal zone of the northeastern Atlantic. Evidence of interspecific hybridization has been found between L. saxatilis and L. arcana (Mikhailova et al., 2009; Granovitch et al., 2013), so it is important to study the mechanisms of reproductive isolation that restrict gene flow between Neritrema species. One of the key mechanisms of prezygotic isolation is gamete incompatibility, which is based on the fast evolution of reproductive proteins (Swanson & Vacquier, 2002). To date, reproductive proteins have not been characterized in Neritrema species. Here we report data on a completely new protein from L. obtusata sperm, which has no homologue in databases, but may play an important role in reproductive isolation between Neritrema species.
title: LOSP: a newly identified sperm protein from Littorina obtusata

content: Molecular evolution of closely related marine intertidal gastropods: from proteomes to localization of genes on chromosomes RFBR #15-04-08210
summary: Molecular evolution of closely related marine intertidal gastropods: from proteomes to localization of genes on chromosomes
title: Molecular and morphological variation in sister species of Littorina

content:
Environmental MAnagement of Petroleum activities in the Barents Sea: Norwegian-Russian collaboration (EMAP) RFBR # 14-04-93083
As the Arctic region is increasingly involved in oil and gas production, the importance of developing common approaches to environmental monitoring is growing. This is especially important for areas of the Barents Sea, where international consortia are developing Norwegian and Russian oil reserves.
We propose taking advantage of the existing cooperation of science and industry in the field of environmental monitoring in the Norwegian sector, as well as the proven history of bilateral interactions of environmental management and environmental expertise between Russia and Norway. In accordance with this, the goal of the proposed project is the development of unified, based on a unified methodology, standards for environmental monitoring of oil production regions, which will significantly improve coordination of efforts of the two countries in applied and basic research of the Arctic region and will make possible a wide exchange of expert assessments between Russian and Norwegian research groups. Leading institutions — the project participants with significant experience in cooperation among each other — will use the opportunities offered by the project to work together to build a common database in three blocks of environmental monitoring of the Arctic shelf: distribution of benthic communities, the impact of pollutants on marine organisms and the geochemistry of hydrocarbons. The taxonomic approach to description of the key faunal groups will be unified, existing biotic indices will be tested to evaluate the potential effect of pollutants on biocenoses. The latest biosensor technologies will be tested to determine pollution thresholds on model species of marine fauna. A general database of hydrocarbon concentration will be created, allowing the use of available methods to analyse distribution and composition of polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) to draw conclusions about the exogenous or endogenous origin of PAHs and the corresponding conclusions about the source of pollution. These efforts, reinforced by efforts to develop joint educational programs within existing related projects, will further strengthen institutional and scientific cooperation that will go far beyond the objectives of this project.
summary: Environmental MAnagement of Petroleum activities in the Barents Sea: Norwegian-Russian collaboration (EMAP)
title: EMAP

summary: There are few examples of host population regulation by macroparasites in stable communities; however, strong impact of parasites on the host individual is obvious in many cases (for example increased mortality, a reduction in fecundity up to the complete castration). Associations between the host populations (periwinkle Littorina obtusata) and prevalence of trematodes was investigated using long-term data (1982–1997) of two L. obtusata populations in the White Sea, northwest Russia. We hypothesized that high prevalence of trematodes will reduce future host population density, and increase mortality. Using a general linear model, we found a significant negative correlation between host population density and the prevalence of the most abundant parasite, Microphallus piriformes in the previous year. We found no correlation between snail reproduction and the prevalence, but observed a significant reduction in middle-aged mollusk abundance which was associated with high prevalence. This indicates the importance of parasite-induced mortality for the dynamics of the host population. There was an association between trematode infection and L. obtusata populations that influence their distribution within littoral zone. The ‘source’ population, located in the lower section of the macrophyte zone, appears to be self-sustaining, controlling the whole population recruitment and dynamics.
title: Long-term population dynamics of Littorina obtusata: the spatial structure and impact of trematodes

summary: Populations of periwinkles Littorina saxatilis (Olivi 1792) and L. arcana Hannaford Ellis, 1978 are well suited for microevolutionary studies, being at the same time closely related and intraspecifically diverse. The divergence between these two sibling species, sympatric over large parts of their distribution areas, is small, the only morphological difference being the pallial gland complex structure in females. Molecular identification is possible with the use of a RAPD nuclear marker (cloned A2.8 DNA fragment) typical for L. arcana. However, in some individuals from sympatric populations molecular and morphological criteria suggest conflicting species affiliation, which may be explained either by hybridization or by shared ancestral polymorphism. We tested the hybridization hypotheses examining the micro-spatial distribution of these two species across the intertidal zone in two distant sites at the Barents Sea. We found that (a) the frequency of putative hybrids in sympatric populations was proportional to the frequency of L. arcana; (b) L. saxatilis bearing A2.8 DNA fragment were almost absent in the lower part of the intertidal zone, where L. arcana was absent too; (c) there was a close positive correlation between the distribution of potential parent molluscs and putative hybrids. Moreover, logistic regression models showed a good agreement between the distribution of putative hybrid frequencies and that of parental species frequencies. All our observations taken together support the hypothesis of hybridization between L. saxatilis and L. arcana. Elucidating the mechanisms that support the species status of these sympatric populations is necessary.
title: Micro-spatial distribution of two sibling periwinkle species across the intertidal indicates hybrdization

summary: Three sister species of rough periwinkles, viz. _Littorina saxatilis_ (Olivi 1792), _L. arcana_ (Hannaford Ellis 1978) and _L. compressa_ (Jeffreys 1865) from the Barents Sea (Russia), the White Sea (Russia) and the Norwegian Sea (Norway) were studied. The identification of two sibling species _L. saxatilis_ and _L. arcana_ is often difficult as both species have extremely similar shell morphology and reproductive systems. Only mature females can be unambiguously distinguished, with a jelly gland present in female _L. arcana_, but which is replaced by a brood pouch containing developing embryos in _L. saxatilis_. No clear-cut diagnostic features have been found to discriminate between males or juveniles of the two species. The very first diagnostic DNA marker (DNA fragment A2.8, 271 bp length) for _L. arcana_ and _L. saxatilis_ separation was developed. The marker was derived from apparently species-specific _L. arcana_ DNA fragments obtained via Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA (RAPD) analysis. This fragment was cloned and sequenced, whereupon specific primers were designed and the amplification was surveyed in a large number of morphologically well-identified females of both species. Subsequently, the specific DNA marker was used for the identification of male _L. arcana_ and partners in copulating pairs. In this way, we obtained evidence of possible interspecific hybridization between the sibling species _L. arcana_ and _L. saxatilis_ living in sympatry in natural populations: the presence of A2.8 fragment in 12% of morphologically well identified _L. saxatilis_ females and its absence in 14% of morphologically well identified _L. arcana_ females. The A2.8 fragment never amplified in _L. saxatilis_ from sites without _L. arcana_. The A2.8 fragment did not amplify in _L. compressa_, not even in microsympatric populations, and we did not observe interspecific copulations between _L. arcana_ and _L. compressa_.
title: A potential species-specific molecular marker suggests interspecific hybridization between sibling species Littorina arcana and L. saxatilis (Mollusca, Caenogastropoda) in natural populations

summary: Metapopulation structure and genetic differentiation among subpopulations will be tightly related to patterns and processes of local adaptation and microevolution. Understanding the mechanisms behind genetic substructuring will aid in the interpretation of species' ecological performances and strategies. The marine gastropod _Littorina fabalis_ occurs in two size morphs – a small and a large – found in microhabitats of different wave exposure, but overlapping in distribution where wave exposure is intermediate. Earlier studies have found substantial genetic differentiation linked to morph in one allozyme locus (arginine kinase), while 29 other allozyme loci reveal no or minute differences between morphs. Here we add new results showing DNA variation in a RAPD marker being tightly linked to the allozyme variation. Indeed, 97% of the snails homozygotic for one of the Ark alleles had a unique DNA band, while 89% of the snails homozygotic for the other Ark allele lacked the marker. We discuss alternative hypotheses explaining the genetic substructure and suggest that the linkage of size, allozyme and DNA traits might be due to a paracentric chromosomal inversion involving loci coding for these traits. A genetic linkage of traits might promote microhabitat specialization of this species, and such a chromosomal transformation may therefore be adaptive.
title: Habitat-related genetic substructuring in a marine snail (Littorina fabalis) involving a tight link between an allozyme and a DNA locus
A comparison of different protocols for RAPD analysis of Littorina

summary: Under construction
title: Norway 2018
